title: How's the water situation?
text:
How's the water situation? 0 comments 
So, what is the water situation in Adams County? In some places, there is an easy answer; just check the local reservoir levels. But because Adams County has no reservoirs, the answer is a little more complicated. There are no major streams flowing into Adams County; the only water source is rainfall. Therefore, rainfall is an important indicator. The level of water in our streams is also an important indicator, as is the level of groundwater. By observing these three indicators, you can get a good handle on how Adams County is doing with our water resources. 
Adams County, on average, receives more than 40 inches of rain per year. To determine how much rain has actually fallen in Adams County, you could go to the Watershed Alliance website, www.adamswatershed.org . Click on Adams County near the upper left, go to bottom of the page, and click on view participation departure data. This will link you to the Middle Atlantic River Forecast Center web page for Adams County.
